item.title: Sinus SOP
item.description: Eat (Spicy, Soup, Hot, Carbs) Drink (Water, Hot Tea) Pill (Zyrtec, Telfast) Shower (Hot) Sleep Rest Early and Long, to prevent damaging sinus and more days of being ill.

item.title: About
item.description: Me in 2 min I’m Andrew, a Malaysian Physics undergrad on a dual-degree programme between Columbia in NY and CityU in HK. I’ve never been the smartest or the most talented in anything. I’m just curious and ask questions. This is my favourite emoji ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è. I’m currently on a gap year, till Sept 2021, documenting my autodidacy on Youtube and here. I’ll love to make new friends, please reach out to me for anything!

item.title: Books
item.description: Non-Fiction Read My notes are automatically generated from Play Books. Highlights - Red: To apply in life. Yellow: Resonating notes. Green: Vocabulary to revise on. Deep Work - Cal Newport Atomic Habits - James Clear Getting Things Done - David Allen Courage to be Disliked - Ichiro Kishimi The Checklist Manifesto - Atul Gawande I have a compiled list of checklists here Essentialism - Greg Mckeown Show Your Work - Austin Kleon How To Be Miserable - Randy J.

item.title: Habits
item.description: I’m a productivity and habit geek, I can’t make do without a list of habits I’m pursuing now can I! Instilling Currently Wake up by 6am Deliberately practice Guitar for 5 min Cold Showers in the morning 5 min morning journals No phone before lunch Exercise daily Code daily Read daily (Anything) Write daily (Anything) Someday Maybe Stay off coffee for a month Greet someone new each day

item.title: Thank You
item.description: I exist on the shoulders of giants. Shoulders of kind, loving, selfless saints who spent time with me, invested in me, guided me. To you all, I am eternally grateful. Thank you for making a difference in this little boy‚Äôs life. Thank you for making this world, a better place to live in. The list and detail below is by no means complete ‚Äì not even close. It is my small attempt in acknowledging the great people in my life.

item.title: On Marriage
item.description: The story As I stood on the side of the altar, observing my best friend stare down the aisle. Pianist starts playing Canon in D, and the bridesmaid leads the bride, gently and slowly, down the aisle. The bride and groom locks gaze, a pleasant smile hangs on their face. As the cousin of the bride and the bride reach the groom, the cousin hands the hand of the bride over to the groom.

item.title: Fear Setting (A Model on Tim Ferriss's Framework)
item.description: Introduction Our decision making process is often irrational. Because we often only have a method of rationalizing the costs and benefits, but no method for rationalizing fear. For an example, assume you want to explore asking an opposite gender out. The benefit, if successful, is being able to go out with the girl and know her better. The cost, if unsuccessful, is shame and time wasted from the rejection. Shame is temporal, exists larger in your imagination.

item.title: Why You Should Show Your Work
item.description: Through my two years of studying at university, I have been graced with many opportunities. Friends who I scored Hackathons with; mentors who guided me on professional and private life matters; gracious recommendation letters that I received for my work; and interviews for jobs and scholarships that I‚Äôve gotten from mutual friends. What is the commonality above? That I have substance. Maybe not, I‚Äôm 100% sure there are many more out there who are more knowledgeable, with better GPA and a CV 10,000 lumen brighter than mine.
